Blog.post: This past Christmas I read a great book called (The Missional Church). This is a must read book for anyone who is struggling with the current system of doing church in the North American context. For many years I had a sense that we needed to view ourselves as missionaries right here in our own back yard. I was so caught up in the book that I read it in just a couple of days. This book was a great affirmation to be moving in the direction of organic church planting that seeks to establish missional communities.

I recently have been sharing our vision and dream of being a missional community in the western suberbs of metro-detroit with some friends. One friend in particular sent me an email that summerizes well what God has placed in my heart. Hi Jim, I guess the appropriate focus-group term is "processing" with regard to your vision for this new church work as described last night. Perhaps it's a reflection of how far I have come in the past few years that I do not simply dismiss your strategy as backsliding, which was what I'd associated with this type of endeavor in the past. Dropping out of "church," leaving "full time ministry" and getting a "real job" would indicate a step in the wrong direction for any servant of God, but you make a compelling argument that has intrigued me like little does, except maybe what to do with my property in (a US state). I wonder if I may articulate your argument in my own words, like the repeating back technique you recommend for communicating with (wife's name), just so I get it? First of all, you are redefining terms. "Church" is not an organizational structure with a payroll, staff, property, or a yellow pages ad. It is not a distinctive meeting time, place, or system of corporate rituals and traditions. It is the pure New Testament description of believers getting together informally in each others homes. There are no committees, preludes, board meetings, or nursery schedules. There are no Sabbath days, no Sunday dresses, polyester suits, or Easter cantatas. Everyone knows pretty much everyone else, no visitor cards, membership classes, or pastor's chats. "Full time ministry" is literally full time, not eight hours a day five days a week, or one morning a weekend. And a "real job" is just a job, where you are a real person, not a figure to whom folks impulsively stop swearing around or take off their hats to. Spiritual gifts are not qualifications to fill slots on an organizational chart, but individual expressions of compassion, love and empathy being used personally to meet needs as they arise. Leaders are not nominated, approved, or elected but simply rise to address occasions as they come up, within the maturity of the individual. Training is not done in a classroom, during a seminar, or over a weekend retreat but while shopping, doing the yard work, at the ball game, washing the car, or killing time during a power outage. It is an environment where there is no image management, since everyone knows you anyway. A safe place away from the world, if only for a few minutes of relief. Kids do not behave one way at school and another at "church" since their peers are their peers. Rather than raising the bar, you propose to lay it on the ground. It would be easy to say that this is simply a knee-jerk reaction to a somewhat frustrating ministry. Your Dad seems to have had a more or less unsatisfying experience as a pastor, Syndie has chafed under her parents church ideas, you both had the church from hell in California, and neither one of you get a full measure of recognition at CCC. However, I know you well enough to know you relish lessons experienced during those learning times, and see them as necessary and profitable parts of preparation for a bigger plan, not a string of disasters. I also realize that pure folly is doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results. I have witnessed God moving so many people in different directions, myself included, that I cannot begin to fathom the complexity of His master plan. I acknowledge that God is not "traditional," and He reserves the right to be results oriented as long as His servants are willing to be "obedience" oriented. Church as we have known it is becoming increasing irrelevant in our culture at large, even as we insist that God is all that is truly relevant. Pitching the last couple of millennium of church is not going to be easy for me. When you first asked me to help you with a church plant, I was not very interested. I can honestly say, this is the most interesting church I have ever conceived. If this is truly God's easy yoke design, I marvel at how complicated we have made it. Will it work?

Church Planting vs Gospel Planting Recently I met a national leader of the Navigator's national metro-city ministries. He made a comment about being a gospel planter verses a church planter. The phrase stuck with me and I emailed him and asked for some more of his thoughts. I will post his thoughts below. He is also very curious for feedback so I will pass along any comments to him. 1. Most church planters have something fairly specific in mind when they go to plant a church, esp. they have cultural forms in mind. This may limit the the audience they will be able to reach and the extent to which the gospel will flow. By this I mean the form that is planted may only be attractive to receptive people. 2. Too often church plants focus on gathering displaced or transitioning Christians. This is a good thing to do, but often diverts attention away from a focus on lost people coming to faith. Actually, this type of church plant can do a lot towards revitalization of faith for those who participate. 3. Gospel planting on the other hand focuses directly on the lost person and their spiritual needs. It is sensitive to their contexts and world view. This is not to imply that church planting can't do this, it just simply means that in my observation it is not the primary concern. 4. Gospel planting seems consistent with what we find in scripture. Paul clearly stated that he was a gospel planter. He was equally clear that God caused the growth. In this way of thinking, we plant the gospel and Jesus builds his church. 5. To make a stark contrast it would seem unlikely that we can plant anything like church as we know it in an Arab Muslim country. However, I would hope that we could plant the gospel of Jesus and His kingdom in any culture, no matter how hostile. The bottom line is this. I am not against church planting in any way. Rather, I want to be sensitive to promoting the purity and mobility of the gospel of Jesus with no cultural add-ons. It is only in this way that the good news of Jesus can reach even the most resistent people. That is my passion. I would appreciate your feedback. I am still waithing to here a yes or no from U of M. Hey All ~ It's Syndie here this time. {BE FOREWARNED.. I just finished typing this and it's really long... sorry! Actually, Jim has been asking me for a couple of days if I wanted to blog about the events of this week. I've been kinda blowing him off... there's been a million details I've had to attend to. But tonight I don't have that excuse. I'm sitting here in Doug and Heather's house... they have gone to Kalamazoo to celebrate Easter with Doug's family. They invited us a bunch of times to go with them.. and Doug's mom invited us too... but we really needed some time alone. So, Doug and Heather graciously gave us a key to their place and told us to make ourselves at home. We had dinner, I made coffee (BTW, Doug, sorry about the regular water in the coffee pot.. I was desperate for some joe! Forgive me!!) Jim just went out to the store to buy some milk and coffee cream and some "good" water so we can make more coffee! Yeah, I know I'm rambling. It's easier to write about coffee than this past week. Bear with me... these thougts will be random and may not make a lote of sense at times. How can I possibly put into words all the feelings, thoguhts, emotions that I have experienced over the last 5 days? I would have to blog for the NEXT 5 days to explain it all. Suffice it to say that I have felt a depth of emotions that I have never thought possible... the deepest terror I have ever known... as I screamed my son's name through the smoke-filled room.. hearing the roar of flames in my ears and the endless amount of time that passed until I found him crouched in a ball behind the door, the anger I felt as it took the Fire Depart ment what seemed like hours to get to our home, the helplessness of watching the smoke billow out the front door and windows of our beautiful house knowing that there was nothing...absolutely nothing I could do... the horror of watching my husband run back into the smoke-filled house in an act of desperation and the girls and I franctically crying and screaming on the front lawn for him to PLEASE come back out of the house... coming out a moment later he said, "But all of our stuff is in there!". And as I screamed at him as loud as I could..."I don't care... let it burn...there's nothing in there as important as you! PLEASE don't go back in! PROMISE ME YOU WON"T GO BACK IN!!!!' I honestly meant it. I love my house. I have blogged before about how much I love our house but in that moment I really didn't care if the whole thing burnt into a pile of ashes... so long as my family was safe. We ran out the door with nothing but the clothes on our backs... the kids and I didn't even have shoes on. As we ran across the street to our neighbors/friends house (Pete & April Laitinen - bless you guys!) it all seemed like a dream. We watched the two huge fire trucks roll up and begin their work...I couldn't watch anymore. Jim ran over and told me to call the insurance company. So I did. And then I called Doug and Heather. I knew I needed them and I knew they would come. Heather wanted to, but the boys were already in bed (although she did tell me that she contemplated pulling them out of bed and coming over with Doug!) As soon as Doug understood what I was saying... (I was crying so hard it was difficult for him to understand me) he said, "I'm on my way." He was there within minutes. My kids all but tackled him as he came in the door. He held them each so gently... he was SO good to our family. He stayed for hours. You all know some of what he has done since then... keeping you all updated with blog entries and pictures... thank you, Doug, my friend. People calling. Dozens and dozens of people calling... how can we help, what can we do... the girls school sent a letter home and people starting bringing in clothes for the kids... tons of them!!! My girlfriends showing up with clothes adn "personal" items for Jim and I... April taking my girls shopping to buy them socks and underwear and shoes...seeings as we ran across the road in our socks! People handing me and Jim cash on more than one occasion, Jim's Thursday night basketball buddies taking him to the mall to buy him a new pair of b-ball shoes... his burned in the fire. Another friend from school brought over 3 personalized Easter Baskets for the kids... figuring that we'd be a little pre-occupied this week and not be able to put Easter Baskets together.... The thoughtfulness and generosity of people has been staggering. Overwhelming really. A friend who just buried her Mom less than 2 weeks ago coming to the door of the house we were staying in with hugs, a financial gift and offers of help in any way... what kind of people are these?? And of course Pete and April, who were in the middle of trying to watch a movie when their lives were interrupted and put on hold as the whole Best family then took up residence in their house (like 7 Laitinen's in the place wasn't enough!!! Why not add 5 Best's too!) April just went into action. She got the spare bed ready, pulled out sleeping bags and pillows and got things ready for the kids... the next day she started washing our smoke-smelly clothes, she became our personal secretary as her phone began ringing off the hook, she accepted donations of food for us and found room in her fridge and freezer for it all, she patiently babysat JJ as we had so much running around to do... Heather has helped me sort through a virtual mountain of donated clothing... what an overwhelming task. Inviting us to dinner, taking JJ to the marshmallow drop even thoguh I couldn't go as planned... Mike and Becky who offered us the keys to their home for this week as they are gogin to be out of town, treating us to dinner, checking in on us daily... my parents who drove over from Canada to take my girls home for a few days. My sister Suzie and her family who have helped take care of Sami and Emily while they are there, my brother Brian and his family who are helping with that task as well, my brother Ben and his wife whom I had to literally had to talk out of coming here the night of the fire. They so wanted to help.. but there really was nothing to do. Jim's bosses as OLGC who gave him the whole week off and then gave him 2 bags of new clothes and an envelope of money to boot! Pat Hovey coming to sort through the wet scrapbooking supplies in my basement to see what could be salvaged... So many others... so much generosity. Indescribable graditude. Thank you to all. So where am I now? Depends on the moment. ~ Feeling tremendous guilt for telling JJ to "get back in your bed" as he knocked on the door after I had tucked him in twice already. The smoke alarm went off about 2 minutes later... ~ feeling SO grateful that I had put the flame resistant jammies on him that night so that the 11 spots that were burned on hs PJ shirt smotherd out rather than igniting him into flames ~ so thankful that Jim had changed the batteries in the smoke detectors ~ Feeling so bad that my children't lives will never be the same again. Will JJ always "freak out" when he sees a smoke detector like he did at the hotel last night? ~ trying to anticipate what the future will hold.... and trying not to think about it at the same time. Too overwhelming righ now. ~ incredible graditude that we all made it out safely ~ struggling with a significant amount of guilt that I am as upset as I am about the "stuff" that was destroyed in the fire. It's only "stuff", right? ~ absolutely ACHING to sit down at my piano and play... Okay... time for me to quit. Jim just said, "Are you STILL typing???" I just scrolled back through this. Sorry. Didn;t mean to go on so... I guess I just uncorked! My deepest graditude to my Savior (with another new dimension to His "saving" ability...) and to all of you who are helping us get through this. Do not miss this fact: GOD IS AT WORK IN THIS SITUATION!!! From the minute we set foot in our home at 1832 Treadwell St. we have prayed that He would use our family and our house to advance His Kingdom in our neighborhood and the school and our relational network. We asked and prayed and looked for ways to connect with people and prayed that God would do whatever He wanted to bring this about. We threw parties, joined the PTA and MOMS clubs and have watched and waited for Him to bring opportunities. Never in my wildest dreams did I think that He would choose to have our house burn in order to advance His Kingdom in this area, but that's exactly what He chose to do. And so we say, The Lord gives, the Lord takes away BLESSED BE THE NAME OF THE LORD! Let Your Kingdom come, Jesus!!

Hi All... Syndie here again. Sorry it's been so long since we updated. Things continue to busy. I'll try and give you all the updates that so many of you have been asking about. First of all I must say a HUGE thank you to all of you. So many of you have sent cards, letters, emails, & calls expressing your love and prayers for us. We are deeply grateful to you for all your expressions of love and we continue to ask for your prayers. We have indeed felt your prayers on our behalf. We are fairly settled in our apartment. It is a nice place and we are thankful to have it. It's not without it's drawbacks (not really thrilled about going back to "apartment living" after having been in our own home...) but it's a heck of a lot better than being in the Holiday Inn for months on end!! It's a 2 bedroom which means we have all the kids in one room again. This has been a bit of a challenge... especially with JJ's sleeping troubles. It's closer to Jim's work but further (MUCH further) from the girls school. It's about a 20 minute drive one way to the school. I have to take Emily at 8:00am, drive home, take Sami at 11:40am, drive home, go and pick up the girls at 2:50. This is taking some getting used to since we were walking to school from our home... it was 3 blocks down the street. This past Monday... after being in our new apartment for all of one week, things were starting to calm down a bit so I guess my kids felt we needed some more excitement in our lives. They were playing and, long story short, Sami ended up getting poked in the eye with a stick. Like really poked. It started bleeding all down her cheek and she was screaming "I can't see!!! I can't see!!!". So, I packed her up and headed off to the ER for just shy of 3 hours. After some pretty extensive proceedures, they removed a small piece of wood/sliver from her eye and treated the 3 cuts in her cornea. They gave her a prescription for drops that she has had to have 4 times a day for the past week. It was pretty scary. Have you every seen an eyeball bleed?? It ain't pretty! Thursday afternoon JJ (and I) had to go to the Fire Station for another "interview". It didn't go so well. He ended up crying, I ended up crying, he still wouldn't talk about it. It's been strange... during all of our driving back and forth to school this week there have been a few times when JJ and I have been alone in the van and out of the blue he'll say something like, "The fire was hot". But as soon as I ask him anything else about it he clams up and won't even look up. It's so sad. It's like he wants to talk about it but he can't. The Fire fighter that we talked to suggested that he see a Therapist, which a couple of friends had suggested earlier as well. So we made some calls and set up an appointment. He went for his first session yesterday afternoon. Typically, he didn't say much about it when asked and he got very upset when I was talking about it to the Doctor (I was crying and this upsets him a lot). He (JJ) is still having trouble going to sleep at night. Every night is a struggle and he wakes up several times even after he does go to sleep. I feel like I have a newborn again. He continues to act out in strange ways too. Like, just now he walked in the room and threw a box of kleenex at my head.. lots of anger. One of the things that the Therapist said was that I should try and have him do things that he used to do before the fire. This morning I was about to put on some laundry so I asked JJ to come help me. This used to be one of his favorite things to do... he would stand on a stool and put in the soap and fabric softener and help put the clothes in. So he came in and got up on the stool and started to put the soap in and then he totally freaked out and started saying, "Stop the smoke Mama, stop the smoke!!" He dropped the soap thing and coverd his face with his hands and started crying and then he ran down the hall and into the bedroom (where Jim was on the computer). He threw himself on the bed and buried his face in the pillows, crying. Jim looked at me and asked, "What the heck happened?" I told him I was doing a load of whites so I put the washer on HOT and he saw the steam and fell apart thinking it was smoke. Jim tried to comfort him. I went back to the washer and a few minutes later Jim came in carrying JJ. JJ had his face covered with his hands again. Jim tried to tell him that it wasn't smoke, it was steam. He wasn't at all interested, he just wanted away from it. It absolutely broke my heart. I stood there crying, putting clothes into the washer trying to tell myself, "It won't always be like this". As far as the house, we are meeting with the Insurance Adjuster at 3:00pm on Monday to go over the non-salvageable list, which should be quite an undertaking. Once he approves that then he will meet with the contrator who will give him the estimate on the house repairs. After the bid is approved they will get the building permit and start to work. Jim talked to the contractor about a possible time frame for it to be completed and the guy said that he figured that it will take about 12 weeks from when they start working. At this point (if they start working by the end of next week) that would put it completed by about the end of July/beginning of August. My only hope in this is that they don't run into any "snags" that will delay things too much because my kids go back to school the last week of August. We really would like a couple weeks to get re-settled in our home before that has to happen. Again, we thank you all so much for your love and prayers. We will continue to keep you updated here when we can. Syndie

It's Syndie again. Several people have asked me why I haven't been writing on my own Blog... hard to explain. If you look, the last day I blogged on mine was the day of the fire. For some reason I can't get past that. No, I didn't say it made any sense, I was just offering an answer to those of you who have asked. This has been a really hard day. I guess it shouldn't come as a surprise since last night was such a hard night. The kids didn't do so well. Emily was fine...slept through the night just fine. Sami was up about 6 times between midnight at 6:00am and JJ was a mess. He told me this morning that he had a dream about the fire last night...like I couldn't have guessed. At almost 1:00am I found him sitting in the middle of the kitchen floor crying. I think he was still asleep. I picked him up and tried to head back to his bedroom and he started yelling, "No, no don't go there". I asked him if he wanted to sleep in my bed. He wasn't making any sense. I took him in bed with me where he stopped crying for a few minutes and then started writhing and screaming, "No!! Get me out.. get me out... get down get down.!!" God only knows the horrors my sweet boy was reliving. This went on (off and on) for several hours before he fell back to sleep. Intermitently in there I had to take Sami back to bed and stay with her while she went to sleep. This morning after I dropped Emily off at school I drove to our house to meet with the Project Manager. He had asked me to come so I could sign off on the paperwork giving them permission to gut the house and throw out any of the remaining contents. As I came up the block I saw the huge 35 foot dumpster in our driveway. It literally took my breath away. The tears came without warning. I'm not sure why this reaction... I'm not sure of many of my emotions these days. It feels like just yesterday that we signed the paperwork to buy this house...our first home. There was somthing so wrong about signing a paper that was titled...DEMOLITION CONSENT. A profound sadness has taken hold of me and I can't shake it.

Another day... I am choosing to put one foot in front of the other today again. It seems to get me to the end of the day somehow. I guess it's Sami's turn to come unglued. Last night we had some pretty good thunder storms roll through here which freaked her out pretty badly. Both she and JJ ended up in our bed (very crowded!) This morning she was just not herself...very whiney and clingy..she spent most of the morning in tears for one reason or another. I took her to school, dropped her off at her class and started walking back to our van. About half way across the lawn of the school I heard Sami screaming, "Mommy!!!!" I turned around to see her come running out of the school just sobbing her heart out. She jumped into my arms and kept saying, "Please don't leave me, Mommy. Please don't leave me.." I'm not sure how much more of the heart-wrenching I can take. Her eyes were full of fear...panic, almost. I tried to calm her and reassure her that everything is okay and that I would be back to pick her up at the end of the day. When I walked her back to class I noticed that her regular teacher wasn't there...she had a substitute. I'm not sure if that just tipped the scale of "displacement and change" in her little life or what. Oh who am I kidding? I have no idea what it was all about. All I know is that I hate how helpless I feel in those situations. I'm trying not to be offended but I'm really starting to get a complex... this is the third bag of clothing donations for me that have been really, really big...todays were all 3X and 4x clothes. I have been really struggling with my emotional eating this past month but I didn't think I had put that much weight back on. Maybe I'm in denial. Today I sat and cried as I looked through all these clothes... I guess it's because they were from one of the other Kidergarten moms. When she gave them to me she said that she had a friend who was "about your size" (meaning me) who had gone through her clothes and packed up this huge bag of them for me. Wow. Is that really how I look to everyone?? yikes. My emotions are still all over the map...somedays I get so tired of crying I could just cry. yeah...that's about how much sense it makes too. For whatever reason I can't seem to make a decision to save my life! I went to buy a hanging flower basket at Walmart and came home without one becasue I just about made myself half crazy trying to decide..."Should I get pansies or begonias? Purple? Yellow? Pink? A 6" pot or an 8" pot? What if it needs full sun and we don't get full sun at the apartment? What if it needs shade and the hook makes it hang in the sun? What if I forget to water it? Maybe I could put it on the ground so it could get the rain water.. what if the kids get into it on the ground and wreck it? What if...what if.... what if?????? " Oh forget it! Welcome to the world inside my head. What a scary place , huh? I've never been a good decision maker but now it's especially bad... I guess I just keep second guessing myself after making a pretty bad decision on the night of April 5th....

The fire was one month ago today (tonight at 9:00, actually). In someways it seems like yesterday. In other ways it seems like a lifetime ago. Sometimes I still think I'm going to wake up and tell Jim that I had this horrible dream about us having a fire... Thanks to all of you for your on-going prayers... JJ has been sleeping much better...thank you Jesus! I'm still struggling in that area. JJ is still having some behaviorial issues and still has a fair amount of sad times... he'll sit and be on the verge of tears and when asked what's wrong he just says, "I don't know". We are getting into a routine of sorts... I'm driving for a little over 2 hours a day (back and forth to school) which, frankly, STINKS! That was one of the big drawing cards for us buying our house... it's right down the street from the school and we were walking there. This takes a big chunk of my day but there really aren't a lot of options. The house is pretty much gutted. I went through it this morning.. there are no walls left upstairs... the bathroom is empty (toilet and sinks are sitting in the garage... those are about 6 weeks old...) Much more I wold like to write, however, JJ is having one of those "behaviorial issuses" at the moment so I must go. I'll write more when I can.

Another day. Thankful for a fairly good night's sleep last night. JJ and Sami both ended up in my bed but at least we didn't have any nightmares like a couple days ago. God is good. We continue to try and process everything... Jim and I walked through the house last week before they started the demolition. Jim summed it up perfectly. He said it felt like we were at an open casket funeral. At a funeral you look at this body lying in a casket and say, "Yes... technically that is 'Grandma' (or whoever)". That is their body. But really, it's not them. There is no life. All the things that made them who they were are not there anymore. That's how it felt at the house. Yes, technically we were walking through "our house" but all the things that made it our home were not there anymore. There was no life in it. It was so empty, a shell with nothing in it... it all felt so hollow. It's hard to feel that way about a place I loved so much. A place where every single time I walked in the door I felt this wonderful feeling of comfort and "right-ness". Ahhh, I'm home. Doesn't feel like that now. Will it ever feel that way again? I don't know. I sure hope so.

It's hard to believe it's almost the middle of May already. The kids are really ready to be outdoors. Thanks for all of your on-going prayers. Nights have been MUCH better! Praise God! We all continue to try and process where we find ourselves and how we're feeling. I'm really struggling with feeling sorry for myself. I keep thinking, "Our big beautiful backyard... the patio in our backyard is bigger than the livingroom and dining area in this apartment combined!... the kids have a swingset in our yard, and a sandbox, and a pool and a mini-trampoline, and a bunch of outdoor toys and games... And our big beautiful maple tree gives wonderful shade on the hot days... We have a fabulous patio set that we love to use for parties and community stuff....I miss it all so much." But then I think of other people who don't have all this nice stuff and may never have any stuff like this... I should be glad that I have what we do have here. And I keep trying to remind myself that it will all be there next summer when we're back in the house. It's hard though. I want to "be content in whatever state I find myself in" )even if it is Michigan..) {okay, that was a joke...}) I was referring to what Paul wrote in the NT somewhere. I really do want to find my contentment in Christ. So why do I feel so displaced? Why do I feel so restless... like I want to go home? Why can't I just have a happy attitude about things here? Well Hello Blogging world! This is Syndie writing again. Been a long time since I chatted here. Things have been going fairly well. The girls finished up school a month ago and we've been on the go ever since. It's good though, it makes the time go by quickly which is a good thing. I need time to go by fast. I am trying to keep a positive outlook on things... somedays are better than others. Things are progressing on the house slowly but surley. Hopefully we should be in the first part of August. I am praying so. I miss my house so much. I have heard it said many times and have now found it to be true that "home is where your heart is". We have been at home here in the apartment becasue we have been together. But I still really miss my house and I am very much looking forward to getting back there and making it "home" again. Although, I must confess... I am NOT looking forward to moving back in. After 8 moves in 10 years of marriage I knew I had found "home" when we moved into the house last year. And as I unpacked boxes ( exactly a year before the fire...) I smiled inside thinking..."I will never again pack or unpack boxes to move. After I am dead and gone my children will sift through all this stuff and question why on earth I had most of it. But it will be them packing and unpacking boxes, not me. I have moved for the last time!!! Ya hoo!!" Well, not exactly. In the next month or so I will, yet again, be unpacking boxes to move into a house. Please, Lord, let this be the last time!!! I am grateful for the ways that I see the kids healing. There's more healing to come, for sure, but things are so much better that before. Sleeping is so much better... thank you all for your prayers... I am trying not to be too worried about moving back into the house but honestly, there are a lot of fears that plague my mind. I'm not sure I'll ever be able to climb the stairs without seeing smoke filling the hallway up there. How will I fall asleep there? Will the kids be afraid? Should I ask them now and try and talk through some if it before we get there or should I not even bring it up? Don't know. This week there was another house fire...right around the corner from our house. One big difference though... in this one, a man died. A 51 year old man is dead. Same fire department responded... same area of town... theirs was during the day,ours was at night. I have been stunned at the number of times all of this has overwhelmed me...the realization that things could have so easily gone so differently for us. Like the one fire fighter said... "Another 60 seconds and the boy would not have come out of there". 60 seconds. A man died. A boy was saved. God, why does it have to be this way? Why not just let everyone have "close calls" so they can look back and reflect on how good You are for saving them? Why would you allow it to go one way for my family and a differnt way for someone elses? Obviously I am so incredibly grateful that You chose to save my family, but why? Was this man older and had lived a full life so it was okay for him to die? What about Jennifer Palmer? Why did she have to die? She wasn't old. She hadn't lived a full life. She had a husband and son who needed her. Waht about the 3 year old little girl who's whose burned down a few days after ours did... but she ran and hid in her parents closet (instead of behind the door like JJ did) and she died there. She hadn't lived a full life. I just don't understand. There was a time in my life when I never would have allowed myself to even THINK these thoughts, let alone put them on paper (or a computer screen, I guess). To question an all-powerful God?? Who do you think you are to question Him? "Ours is not to question why, ours is but to do and die." God, thanks for being big enough to allow me to struggle through this without 'offending' You. Thanks for allowing me to question things, understanding all the while that it's coming from a heart that desperately loves You and really wants to know You and needs to see you in the reality of the mess that i find myself in.

Syndie here again. Sometimes I wonder why things happen. Yesterday I was at a playgroup that has developed out of some good friendships I have made with other moms of kids in Sami's class at school. After the school year ended we decided we wanted to stay connected through the summer so we get together every Tuesday at Lisa'a house to let the kids swim and play together and us moms have a chance to hang out and talk. Weve' been doing this for about 6 weeks and it is becomming a highlight of my week. Most of my friends at this group are not Christ followers (yet) but we have had some really great discussions about "stuff". It's a very good thing and I'm honored to be a part of it. Since the fire I have been on "heightened alert" for seeing smoke, smelling smoke... smelling tings burning... like the day I ran the kids out of the apartment because I was SURE I saw smoke coming out of the back of the washer and dryer in the laundry area... I have embarasses myself on more than one occassion saying, "Do you smell smoke? Does that look like smoke coming out of there?" Most of my friends just smile and pat my arm in that "way" and say, "No, Syndie, there's no smoke anywhere. Everything's fine." I have tried to stop asking those questions before they lock me up in a looney bin somewhere. Back to yesterday... we're sitting out on the deck at Lisa's house talking, laughing, watching the kids play... when I'm sure I smell smoke. Not a lot, but I smell it. Then I look towards the neighbors' backyard and I think I see smoke coming up from their house. I talk myself out of saying anything... "they're probably just grilling somthing for lunch... it is lunchtime after all." I tell myself. Then I hear sirens. Soft at first, then louder and louder... the house was on fire. 50 feet away from where I'm sitting the house was on fire. Of course all the kids had to run to the front yard to see the comotion... Sami and JJ among them. As JJ rounded the corner to the front of the house and caught sight of the smoke and the fire trucks and all the terror in his eyes was almost more than I could take. Then the smell hit both of us. Lisa took JJ as I ran for the bathroom where I threw up and sat crying. I tried to pull myself together for the kids and we quickly packed up and left. I had no idea that this would affect me physically like it did. All the way home JJ kept saying, "Mommy, I don't feel good." I knew exactly how he felt. Last night I ended up with 2 extra little people in my bed for most of the night. It feels like a scab has just been ripped off of an nicely healing wound and now it's bleeding all over again. Why?
